title: Why do atomic spectra appear as lines? - Quora

response.answer_text: The instruments generating the results work like a prism.  So, the concentration of photons at 420nm, then 680nm, or such, would show as different distances = the angle of deflection. That is a direct correlation = wavelength > angle of deflection.

The lines in atomic spectra are images of the slit used to view the light source. The slit is a line, so the spectra shows up as lines. If the slit were a circle (a pinhole) then the spectra would look like circles.
